content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the ultimately enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for consultation. The federal government spending process involves budget authority enacted by Congress, funds obligated by federal agencies, and payments made to liquidate those obligations. Budget authority is determined through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation, and agencies are prohibited from obligating more funds than enacted by Congress. Budget authority may also be indefinite in amount. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation and determines the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted by Congress. Budget authority may be one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis, with unobligated funds at the end of the year no longer available for spending. Multiyear budget authority specifies a range of time for spending, while no-year budget authority is available for an indefinite period. Budget authority is available for obligation during a specific fiscal year, with unobligated funds no longer available for spending at the end of that year. Multiyear budget authority allows funds to be obligated over a specified time period, while no-year budget authority is available for an indefinite period. Obligations are incurred when federal agencies engage in transactions, creating a legal requirement for the government to pay. Outlays represent the actual funds spent during the fiscal year, which may not always match the budget authority enacted. Budget authority can be obligated in one fiscal year but spent in a future year, especially with certain contracts. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. It consists of discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary funds appropriated yearly by Congress. Gross budget authority for federal agencies includes discretionary and mandatory spending. Discretionary spending is annually appropriated by Congress, while mandatory spending is provided in laws outside of appropriations acts. Offsetting collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of business-type transactions, not considered federal revenue but counted as negative outlays. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending.
